text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A square is divided into 4 equal quadrants, with each quadrant labeled as follows: the top-left is white, the top-right is black, the bottom-left is black, and the bottom-right is white.
If this square is reflected across a vertical line running through its center, what will be the resulting pattern? Describe which quadrants will be white and which will be black after the reflection.

Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I've got this problem here about a square divided into four equal quadrants, each labeled with colors: top-left is white, top-right is black, bottom-left is black, and bottom-right is white.
The question is asking what happens to the pattern when the square is reflected across a vertical line running through its center.
Hmm, okay, let me try to visualize this.
First, let me sketch this out in my mind.
The square has four quadrants: top-left (white), top-right (black), bottom-left (black), and bottom-right (white).

So, if I imagine the square on a coordinate plane, with the center at the origin (0,0), the quadrants would be as follows:

- Top-left: Quadrant I (white)
- Top-right: Quadrant II (black)
- Bottom-left: Quadrant III (black)
- Bottom-right: Quadrant IV (white)

Now, reflecting across a vertical line through the center means we're flipping the square horizontally.
So, any point (x, y) in the original square will be mapped to (-x, y) in the reflected square.
But wait, reflection across the vertical line through the center is a bit different.
It's like flipping the square left to right.
So, the left side becomes the right and vice versa, but the top and bottom stay the same.
Let me think about each quadrant and where they end up after reflection.
Starting with the top-left quadrant (Quadrant I, white).
Since we're reflecting across the vertical center, this quadrant will move to the top-right side of the square.
So, after reflection, the area that was top-left becomes top-right.
Since the original top-left was white, the reflected top-right will also be white.
Next, the top-right quadrant (Quadrant II, black).
This quadrant is on the right side of the square.
After reflection, it will swap places with the left side's top-left quadrant.
So, the original black top-right becomes the new left side's top-left.
Therefore, the reflected top-right quadrant will now be black.
Moving on to the bottom-left quadrant (Quadrant III, black).
This is on the left side, below the center.
After reflection, it will move to the bottom-right side of the square.
Since the original bottom-left was black, the reflected bottom-right will also be black.
Lastly, the bottom-right quadrant (Quadrant IV, white).
This is on the right side, below the center.
After reflection, it will move to the bottom-left side of the square.
So, the original white bottom-right becomes the new bottom-left.
Therefore, the reflected bottom-left quadrant will now be white.
Wait a second, let me make sure I got that right.
The top-left goes to top-right and remains white.
The top-right goes to top-left and becomes black.
The bottom-left goes to bottom-right and remains black.
The bottom-right goes to bottom-left and becomes white.

So, after reflection, the quadrants would be:

- Top-left: Originally white, now black (since top-right moved here)
- Top-right: Originally black, now white (since top-left moved here)
- Bottom-left: Originally black, now white (since bottom-right moved here)
- Bottom-right: Originally white, now black (since bottom-left moved here)

So, the new pattern after reflection should have the top-left as black, top-right as white, bottom-left as white, and bottom-right as black.
I think that makes sense.
Each quadrant is swapping places horizontally across the vertical center line, so their colors are also swapping accordingly.
I should double-check to make sure I didn't mix up any quadrants.

Original Quadrants:
- TL: White
- TR: Black
- BL: Black
- BR: White

After Reflection:
- TL becomes TR's color: Black
- TR becomes TL's color: White
- BL becomes BR's color: White
- BR becomes BL's color: Black

Yes, that seems consistent.
So, the resulting pattern after the reflection would have the top-left and bottom-right quadrants as black, and the top-right and bottom-left as white.
I don't think I made any mistakes here.
Each quadrant's reflection is straightforward since it's a simple horizontal flip.
So, the final pattern should look like a checkerboard again but with the colors swapped in the top and bottom halves.

</think>

After reflecting the square across the vertical center line, each quadrant's position is mirrored on the opposite side.
The original top-left and bottom-right quadrants (white) become the top-right and bottom-left, respectively, while the original top-right and bottom-left (black) become the top-left and bottom-right.

Resulting Pattern:
- Top-left: Black
- Top-right: White
- Bottom-left: White
- Bottom-right: Black

DONE.
